tool.name: FROGSSTAT DESeq2 Preprocess
tool.description: import a Phyloseq object and prepare it for DESeq2 differential abundance analysis

param.name: analysis
param.label: Type of analysis
param.help: Type of data to perform the differential analysis. ASV: DESeq2 is run on the ASV abundance table. FUNCTION: DESeq2 is run on predicted function abundance table from FROGSFUNC_2_function tool.

param.name: data
param.label: Phyloseq object
param.help: This is the result of FROGSSTAT_Phyloseq_Import_Data without normalisation (DESeq2 is more powerful on unnormalised counts) (format RData)

param.name: input_functions
param.label: Function abundances file
param.help: Input file of predicted function abundances (frogsfunc_functions_unstrat.tsv from FROGSFUNC_2_function tool).

param.label: Sample file (format: TSV)
param.help: The file must contain the metadata that characterise each sample.

param.name: var1
param.label: Experimental variable
param.help: The factor that could have an effect on ASV/FUNCTION abundances. Ex: Treatment, etc.

param.name: seconde
param.label: Do you want to correct a confounding factor?
param.help: If yes, specify the counfouding factor

param.name: mod
param.label: Type of model
param.help: Choose an additive model (+) if the effects of Treatment and Gender are independent. Choose a model with interaction (*) if the effect of Treatment is expected to depend on Gender.

tool.help:
@HELP_LOGO@
.. class:: infomark page-header h2
What it does
This tool launches Rscript to compute differential abundance analysis using `DESeq2 <https://bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/DESeq2.html>`_ on a `Phyloseq <https://joey711.github.io/phyloseq/>`_ object.
.. class:: infomark page-header h2
Inputs/Outputs
.. class:: h3
Input
Two cases :
-1. for **ASV**: A **phyloseq object** stored in a Rdata file. This file is the result of FROGSSTAT Phyloseq Import Data. We need unnormalised data to analyse the abundance differencies.
.. class:: warningmark
We need unnormalised data to analyse the abundance differencies.
-2. For **FUNCTION**: two files: - the files that contains predicted **function abundances**, it is named frogsfunc_functions_unstrat.tsv and produced by FROGSFUNC_2_function tool. - the file that must contain the **metadata** that characterise each sample i.e. the conditions of experiment with sample ID in the first column as:
.. image:: FROGS_Phyloseq_samplefile.png :height: 115 :width: 369
.. class:: h3
Ouput
Two cases :
1. For **ASV**: a **dds.object** that is a DESeq2 dataset (dds) stored in Rdata file. This result will be one of the input of the FROGSSTAT DESeq Visualisation tool. 2. For **FUNCTION**: - a **dds.object** that is a DESeq2 dataset (dds) stored in Rdata file. This result will be one of the input of the FROGSSTAT DESeq Visualisation tool. - a **abundance.Rdata** taht contains information of data in one phyloseq object.
.. class:: infomark page-header h2
How it works ?
The DESeq2 function performs a default analysis through the steps:
1. estimation of size factors: ‘estimateSizeFactors’
2. estimation of dispersion: ‘estimateDispersions’
3. Negative Binomial GLM fitting and Wald statistics: ‘nbinomWaldTest’
You must precise at least on variable on which the differential abundances will be compared.
You may precise a confounding factor, by adding an other variable and you may precise the relation between the two variables:
- for independant variables - for interacting variables
